chunks.chunk_text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Beth. And I'm Neil.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: What's more, fandom has started to develop its own language. In this programme, we'll be taking a trip into the world of fandoms and, as usual, we'll be learning some new and useful vocabulary too. But before that, I have a question for you, Neil.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: I'll guess they were fans of Disney cartoons. OK, Neil. We'll find out later in the programme. Michael Bond is the author of a new book, Fans. Here, he discusses the meaning of fandom with BBC Radio 4 programmes
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json
RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: Fans are groups of like-minded people. They share similar opinions, ideas or interests. They do all kinds of weird and wonderful things together, such as dressing up as Harry Potter characters, behaviour which might be called quirky – an adjective meaning odd or unusual, but in an interesting way.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: Unfortunately, this quirky behaviour also means fans sometimes get mocked. To mock somebody means to insult them by laughing at them in an unkind way. But this hasn't discouraged fans who have started using new words and phrases to show they belong to a particular fandom. Here's Michael Bond again, explaining the meaning of two new words about the behaviour of football fans to BBC Radio 4 programme Word of Mouth.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json
RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: Loses and they don't want to be associated with that loss, that sense of failure.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: The opposite of burging is corphing – another acronym, this time of the words cutting off reflected failure. Corphing involves distancing yourself from the team you support when they lose. Instead of saying we won, you say they played rubbish.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: I can't imagine that's true of the Americans you mentioned, Beth. So what was the correct answer to your question?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: As they were called at the time. OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt, starting with like-minded – an adjective describing people who share similar opinions, ideas or interests. Quirky means odd or unusual, but in an attractive or interesting way. If you mock someone, you insult and laugh at them in an unkind way. Burging is short for basking in reflected glory. It means feeling good about yourself
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How fans talk about their passions.json

chunks.chunk_text: when the team you support wins. The opposite of this is corphing – an acronym of cutting off reflected failure, which means distancing yourself from your favourite team when they lose. And finally, if you want a piece or a slice of the action, you want to take part in a celebration or other exciting group activity to include yourself in a collective success.
